data.text:
That Hindi cinema is much more than mainstream boxoffice hits is refrain of cinema enthusiasts. A special feature on Zee Classic aims to reinforce this fact by showcasing some excellent parallel cinema with India’s Finest Films: A Parallel Journey which includes the country's finest Hindi alternative cinema (including ones produced by the National Film Development Corporation (NFDC)) as well as gems such as Mirch Masala, Ek Doctor ki Maut, 27 Down and Salaam Bombay, at 10pm every Saturday, until October 15.

Each screening will be preceded by interviews with stalwarts who pushed the movement from Shyam Benegal to Mahesh Bhatt, Saeed Mirza and Kundan Shah. Viewers also have the opportunity to watch the debuts of actors such as Irrfan Khan and Pankaj Kapur to Naseeruddin Shah.

The showcase also shows recent films by the likes of directors such as Anurag Kashyap and Tigmangshu Dhulia. Below are a few films from the showcase we think you should watch.

Ek Doctor Ki Maut (1990)

This National Award winning film stars Pankaj Kapur and Shabana Azmi and is directed by Tapan Sinha. Dr Dipankar Roy, after discovering a vaccine for leprosy, becomes a victim of professional jealousy. He suffers the ultimate betrayal when credit for his achievement goes to others.

Gangoobai (2013)

Produced by NFDC and directed by Priya Krishnaswamy, this 2013 film stars Sarita Joshi as Gangoobai, an elderly maid works towards her dream of an unaffordable Gara sari. In the process, she changes the lives of people she interacts with, while also influencing the course of her own life.

Arvind Desai Ki Ajeeb Dastaan (1978)

Directed by Saeed Akhtar Mirza, the film dwells on the conflict of the son of a rich businessman. Starring actors such as Shreeram Lagoo, Rohini Hattangadi, Satish Shah, Suresh Oberoi (in a cameo), Om Puri and Dilip Dhawan.

27 Down (1974)

Awtar Krishna Kaul directs a film in which the lead character, Sanjay (MK Raina) is on a pilgrimage to Varanasi when he remembers his life in flashbacks. Sanjay has given up his dreams to be an artist in order to support his family. He is forced to accept the job of a ticket checker until he meets an insurance employee, Shalini (Raakhee), on a suburban train. They fall in love and Sanjay starts to look at life differently. But his father has other plans and he fixes Sanjay up to marry another girl.

Salaam Bombay! (1988)

Directed by Mira Nair with a screenplay by Sooni Taraporevala, the film chronicles lives of street children in Mumbai. It won multiple awards including at Cannes and Montréal festivals. It follows the lives of Krishna, Manju, Sola Saal and Chillum among others, opening with Krishna setting fire to his bullying elder brother's motorbike which lands him in trouble with his mother who gives him the ultimatum that he work and earn Rs500 to pay for the damage. Krishna agrees to work for the circus which packs up and moves on without him.
